channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #199 - Rust 1.0 is out!
item.description:
Hi,

More of you (ok, us) should follow Joel Berger's example: write about your new modules.

If you're looking for a project to work on, check our Mark Dominus's list of unfinished projects.

Editor #3, Neil
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: Joel's recent CPAN modules
item.description: Joel gives us a quick tour of six modules that he's released recently. Five are Mojo-related, plus Webservice::Shipment which provides a standard interface for getting shipping updates from carriers (currently UPS and USPS).

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Plack::Middleware::SignedCookies
item.description: Aristotle has released Plack::Middleware::SignedCookies to CPAN. It is Plack middleware that "signs outgoing cookies on the server with a HMAC digest and verifies the digest on incoming cookies. If a cookie doesnâ€™t pass the signature test, it is dropped on the floor and your application never gets to see it".

item.title: Which should I use: Starman or Starlet?
item.description: Miyagawa wrote up a discussion from the plack IRC channel on the difference between two popular Plack servers: Starman and Starlet.

item.title: My Second NYC Perl Hackathon experience
item.description: Charlie shares his experiences with us, both helping organize and participate in the recent New York hackathon. As a result I now know what an alley-oop is.

item.title: Script-fu: how to raise 641 request tracker tickets
item.description: David describes what he did at the New York Hackathon: writing a Perl 5 script to submit a whole heap of Perl 6 tickets.

item.title: How I didn't fix AnyEvent::ForkManager
item.description: Choroba describes his efforts to try and resolve some CPAN Testers failures for AnyEvent::ForkManager. Ultimately he was unsuccessful — maybe you can take a look and help him out?

item.title: The world of MongoDB
item.description: Mark continues his series about companies using Perl, this time with MongoDB.

item.title: Miniconf NYC - a free Perl conference
item.description: Following the demise of Mojoconf, David and Richard Elberger are organising a mini conference in New York on Saturday 6th June. Current plans include training, a hackathon, and lightning talks. Plus swag!

item.title: DBIC Training in Granada
item.description: Dave's giving a one-day introductory course on DBIx::Class at YAPC::EU this year.

item.title: Which CPAN distributions include jquery.js ?
item.description: Gabor's continuing his experimentation with an alternative interface for searching CPAN. He's added an interface that lets you find all distributions that contain a given filename.

item.title: Perl Zombie Ate My Brain
item.description: Byterock describes his experience adding an async call into an existing website. Tests in development worked fine, but releasing it on production quickly resulted in hundreds of zombie processes...

item.title: Want to work with me on one of these projects?
item.description: Mark lists some of his unfinished projects. He's hoping some of us might be interested in working on these, either with Mark or not.

item.title: Veure: Arbitrary Mission Actions
item.description: Ovid continues his series about the game, code-named Veure, that he's developing.

item.title: Last week: smaller hashes, faster startup, and many fixes
item.description: Jonathan covers what he did in the first week of May (he's catching up after OSDC.no): reducing the memory used by hashes, improving Rakudo's startup time on MoarVM, and fixing various bugs.

item.title: 2015.19: Events & Conferences
item.description: A summary of many Perl 6 things going on at various events.

item.title: Less worse command line editing in the perl6 repl
item.description: Rik's puttering with the Perl 6 REPL.

item.title: Maintaining the Perl 5 Core: Dave's monthly report
item.description: There's probably not much in this, relatively short, list, but I think it's important we all acknowledge it. This is a key part of the grind that keeps Perl 5 moving forward.

item.title: Maintaining the Perl 5 Core: Tony's monthly report
item.description: Tony's latest report on his work on Perl 5.

item.title: Announcing Rust 1.0
item.description: The first stable release of the Rust programming language was announced this week. "Rust combines low-level control over performance with high-level convenience and safety guarantees. Better yet, it achieves these goals without requiring a garbage collector or runtime, making it possible to use Rust libraries as a 'drop-in replacement' for C". Rust's equivalent of CPAN is crate.io, which currently has 2,092 crates.

item.title: The Internet of Things â€“ A Primer
item.description: A high-level introduction to "the internet of things": what it is, what tech is involved, and the areas affected.

item.title: Dedicated to documentation (a call for proposals)
item.description: A new community column, doc dish, dedicated to documentation. The first article is RTFM? How to write a manual worth reading. Scroll down and you'll probably recognise someone.
